narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: the course was excellent. Although I found it extremely beneficial that the instructor allowed us to select our analysis software (SAS, R, SPSS, SATA), and even though the instructor made enormous effort to cover guidance for each program, I feel that this added a layer of complexity and took time from teaching the material.Yet, I feel the value of allowing students to select their preferred software is great, and appreciate that option very much. I think in the future, there should be TA's that are experienced in all software students are using in the course. The TA's at CSSSI were very helpful with understanding SAS from a high level, but were not always familiar with the content we were covering in class.

Wonderful instructor! However, I had trouble understanding the material. This was in part due to my limited background in stats, but I think the course may have been a little too fast paced as well. I know there's a lot of material to cover, but if the lectures were a little easier to absorb, then I would feel like I have a much better grasp of the material. Either that, or make the intro the stats course a prerequisite.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: the professor! it's a lot of material and some of it is really hard to conceptualize but he did a great job of presenting things in several different ways so that students stuff out no matter how they think about math.

Dr. Reuning-Scherer is excellent--he made lectures engaging and notes provided for lectures were complete and comprehensive. I really liked that he encourages use of students' own data for homework assignments, as this makes the analyses more meaningful.
Teacher, homeworks
Excellent lecturerMultiple software packages to select fromInstructor went above and beyond to be available for studentsHomeworks' were an *excellent* way to complement the fast-paced lecture style
statistical methods are very useful. office hours are useful.
Learning various statistic technique
Well organized and there were plenty of help sessions. The homework was useful

The course provides a great overview of multivariate statistics with an emphasis on application. Homework assignments and the final project allow you to work on a project of your own interest, provided you have the data available. The homework assignments also allow ample time to explore the different statistical programs out there.
The course gave me a good understanding of how to use a variety of statistical programs.

Professor knows what is the point of learning and dealing with statistics for most of students; he provides exactly what students need in understanding a certain concept of statistics. I didn't have to struggle with all stat equations or mathematical parts, allowing me focus more on principles and applications of those concepts.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: It's a lot of material but that's unavoidable. I'm grateful to have the notes as well, they're very detailed and will help me as I reference these concepts later
Some topics seem to go pretty fast.
None, I doubt anyone teaches it better.
The course is very fast paced and at times I felt I was not keeping along.
nothing
The lectures have great energy, but can move too fast. On the plus side, very little time is wasted and a lot of material is covered.
See question 15

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
Yes.
The all discussions with the professor were super helpful.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: TA's were not familiar with SAS even though the professor a) recommended it as an option and b) referenced it in lecture material.I feel if TA's are going to be selected for the course there should be at least one well-versed in each software.
Instructor: Emily Elizabeth Oldfield  Emily and Sanghee were both wonderful TAs!
Instructor: Sanghee Cho  She is really helpful
Instructor: Sanghee Cho  Sanghee was very helpful and had good command over the material but it was sometimes difficult to tell what she was looking for in grading the hw.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I'm an FES student and my master's project was mostly analyzing a survey. This was very helpful, I just wish I took it before I conducted the survey (spring of last year) rather than this year and I would have organized things a little differently in the survey. I definitely feel much more confident with analyzing social science data after this course. I'm really considering a PhD now and had been pretty intimidated before.
I think this course fits very well, as applied multivariate methods are important for various public health study designs.
I like data, and I wanted to understand how I can gain deeper insights into the data's structure, relationships between variables, and bring statistical rigour to my analysis.
I wanted to learn a more challenging stats software. I do not expect to use statistics directly in my work, but feel it is important to have exposure.
To learn various statistic techniques would be helpful in designing future study

I knew that I would be encountering datasets with multiple response variables in ecological work. I also work in GIS and remote sensing, where some of these techniques also come into play (although usually in background processes). I wanted a solid foundation of understanding in multivariate statistics so I could be prepared for these instances.
To be honest, I'm not exactly sure how this course fits into my overall program (MEM). However, I think it has helped me gain a better understanding of stats that I can use in the future
Of course stats are important especially multivariate analysis method is a core of proceeding science based research.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn about how to analyze my already collected-data for my master's project (and it looks like it will bepublished!) Hooray math!
I wanted an applied statistics class, and this one seemed like a good fit for what I was looking for.
See Q20
above.
use multivariate methods in my research.
To learn various statistic techniques would be helpful in designing future study
Develop quantitative skills.
Recommendation of fellow students
I was told the professor is great.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes!
Exceeded
Yes, it was a great introduction to multivariate methods, and while I might not be an expert in these techniques, having exposure to these will be beneficial when I encounter them in the future.
Yes
yes.
yes.
Yes
Yes.
Yes
Yes, I would like to recommend this course whoever wants to improve their understanding in multiple stat concepts.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Very useful to work on a team for this course. Although I would have learned more on my own it was most efficient to accomplish as a team.
we can discuss both advantages and disadvantages of assignments and projects.
No advantage of groups.
Advantages - sharing the workload. Disadvantages - not learning as much as I would have had I been required to do the work on my own.
Working in a group definitely made the homework assignments easier, and I would definitely recommend that future students work in groups.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do it! It's interesting and extremely applicable
Very useful
Definitely do the legwork in the beginning to find a large dataset that you can use throughout the semester.
Do it.
work with you own data consistently
Get a dataset early on and clean it up early on.
Pay close attention in class!
Work in a group, solo work gets you behind fast. Don't be afraid to ask the TA's and statlab consultants early.
If you're interested in learning multivariate statistics, and having a good review of univariate statistics, then this is a great class. JDRS is, as always, a great teacher.
